questions.text: A female patient is admitted following a domestic assault during which she sustained an isolated head injury. On admission she had a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 13/15 but remained confused. She was therefore admitted overnight for observations. You are called to see her by the high-dependency unit nurses who have noticed a drop in her Glasgow Coma Scale score to 8/15. On examination you note her left pupil is now fixed and dilated. The most likely cause of this is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Uncal herniation
This patient presented with a moderate brain injury. Up to 20% of such patients can be expected to deteriorate or become comatose. The first thing to consider is an expansion of an intracranial haemorrhage with subsequent raised ICP. The Monro–Kellie concept is useful in explaining why intracranial bleeding may initially be compensated for but, once the threshold for compensation is exceeded, eventually results in rapid decompensation unless intervention supervenes. The cranial vault has a fixed volume; bleeding within the skull has a mass effect and therefore some of the existing volume must be sacrificed. This is initially possible since venous volume and CSF volume can be lost, hence the initial period of compensation. However, once haematoma volume exceeds approxi- mately 150 mL, the ability for the venous and CSF compartments to com- pensate is overwhelmed and ICP rises exponentially with further added volume. With increased ICP, arterial flow is compromised and brain mat- ter is under pressure, leading to herniation.
Most commonly, the result is uncal herniation; the uncus is the medial part of the temporal lobe, which may be pushed against the edge of the tentorial notch. This puts pressure on the III cranial nerve, which runs along the edge of the tentorial notch, resulting first in loss of parasympa- thetic supply, then complete oculomotor palsy. The motor tracts are also vulnerable, positioned superficially at that level of the midbrain. Therefore the typical signs of uncal herniation include ipsilateral parasympathetic ± motor oculomotor nerve palsy with motor weakness. Confusion can arise when considering the motor signs of uncal herniation; hemipare- sis can be contralateral or ipsilateral (Kernohan’s phenomenon) to the lesion depending on the severity of herniation. Therefore, all head injury patients with altered consciousness, third nerve and motor signs should be referred for immediate emergency neurosurgical consultation.

choices.text: A zone of hyperemia inside a zone of stasis
A zone of hyperemia superficial to a zone of stasis, with a deeper zone of coagulation beneath
A zone of coagulation at the surface of a burn wound, a zone of stasis within the injured dermal layer, and a deep zone of hyperemia characterized by vasodilated subcutaneous vessels
A zone of coagulation, surrounded by a zone of stasis, which is surrounded by a zone of hyperemia

questions.text: Jackson’s zone of burn injury is shown below. Which of the following statements regarding the order or description of the zones of injury is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Jackson’s classification of zones of injury in 1953 referred to the varying depth of injury radiating outward from a burn wound and defined the pathophysiology of cutaneous thermal injury. The central zone of coagulation is necrotic and irreversibly damaged; it represents a full-thickness injury that will require excision and grafting. The zone of stasis refers to the immediately surrounding region and is characterized by constricted vessels and hypoxia. Initially viable, this tissue may convert to coagulation or a full-thickness injury as a result of edema, infection, or shock with decreased perfusion. The zone of stasis may remain viable if adequately perfused. In a patient with a large-TBSA burn, the viability of this zone may be critical in providing donor sites and reducing the total area that requires grafting. The zone of hyperemia surrounding this is characterized by vasodilation as a result of inflammatory mediators and is viable.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe epigastric pain and mild elevations in lipase (3 x ULN) diagnostic of acute pancreatitis.   The patient describes multiple episodes of pain and associated pancreas enzyme elevations since early childhood that generally respond to brief hospitalizations and conservative treatment including intravenous fluids and IV  analgesics.  CT imaging reveals parenchymal calcifications seen throughout the pancreas.  Further history discloses two relatives with similar pain attacks. Which of the following gene mutations is most likely to be associated with the cause of the recurrent pancreatitis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

RATIONALE The PRSS1 mutation has been shown to be the causative genetic factor in hereditary pancreatitis.  Hereditary Pancreatitis is an autosomal dominant gene mutation with 80 percent penetrance. Symptoms start in childhood with acute recurrent pancreatitis and progress to chronic pancreatitis, diabetes and exocrine insufficiency.  The incidence of pancreatic cancer is increased to 40 percent by age 70.  BRCA1 mutations have been associated with familial pancreas cancer families. SPINK mutations have been associated with chronic tropical pancreatitis. Delta F508 is the most common mutation in cystic fibrosis that leads to pancreas insufficiency in childhood.  The clinical scenario is classic for hereditary pancreatitis.

choices.text: Repeat ERCP with pancreatic duct stent  placement

questions.text: A 21-year-old female underwent ERCP for choledocholithiasis. Biliary cannulation was difficult and a needle-knife sphincterotomy was performed.  Stones were removed and occlusion cholangiogram did not reveal any filling defects. The next morning,  the patient presents with severe epigastric abdominal pain,  nausea and vomiting.  Her lipase is 4000 IU/L  (normal 0-60 IU/L). What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

RATIONALE This patient presents with post-ERCP pancreatitis. Regardless of the cause of acute pancreatitis, the immediate treatment is aggressive,  goal-directed intravenous fluids with lactated ringers.  Lactated Ringers has been shown to decrease SIRS response and CRP levels in patients with acute pancreatitis.  There is no indication for abdominal imaging given the diagnosis is clear based on clinical criteria (history and elevated lipase levels).   Corticosteroids have not been shown to decrease the risk of pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 54-year-old alcoholic male with a history of recurrent acute pancreatitis undergoes a CT scan for abdominal pain that reveals pancreatic parenchymal calcifications and a dilated main pancreatic duct of 11 mm.  There is no evidence of a pancreatic mass or evidence of duodenal obstructive symptoms. What is the best long term management of pain in this patient with chronic pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

RATIONALE Surgical resection / drainage is the best longterm option for symptomatic “large duct” chronic pancreatitis.   Patients with a diffusely dilated duct (as above), are the best candidates for a drainage procedure,  such as the lateral pancreaticojejunostomy.   A randomized controlled trial compared lateral pancreatico-jejunostomy to ERCP with pancreatic stenting (+/- lithotripsy), and found that surgical treatment led to improved pain control at 24 months follow-up. Patients with focal ductal disease and pain can be managed by surgical resection of the diseased ductal segment.  (Whipple,  distal pancreatectomy).  Chronic pancreatitis patients with “small duct” disease are often times considered for TPIAT.

questions.text: A 64-year-old male with a recent history of acute pancreatitis has a dilated main pancreatic duct with prominent side branch lesions seen on CT scan.  Endoscopic  evaluation  reveals  mucus  extruding from a dilated ampulla.   What is the next best step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

RATIONALE This patient has a main duct IPMN, which has a high potential for malignant transformation and should be resected if possible.   Resection is also indicated for branch-duct IPMN’s which are symptomatic (e.g.  pancreatitis),  associated with obstructive jaundice or main duct involvement, have a solid component within the cyst,  or have concerning features on EUS-FNA.

choices.text: Tension pneumothorax; tube thoracostomy 5th intercostal space, anterior to mid-axillary line
Simple pneumothorax; tube thoracostomy 5th intercostal space, anterior to mid-axillary line
Chylothorax; immediate insertion of large-bore cannula, 2nd inter- costal space, mid-clavicular line

questions.text: You are asked to see a 45-year-old female patient on the ward. She is approximately 30 minutes following the insertion of a left internal jugular vein catheter sited for total parenteral nutrition. A plain film chest radiograph has not yet been performed following the procedure. The nursing staff is concerned as the patient is breathless. On arrival, the patient's air- way is patent, but she is breathless at rest. Her respiratory rate is 30 breaths/ min. The trachea is central. Her pulse is 110 beats/min and blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg. There are reduced breath sounds on the left and the left chest is hyper-resonant to percussion. Select the most appropriate diagnosis and management strategy.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Simple pneumothorax; tube thoracostomy 5th intercostal space, anterior to mid-axillary line This patient has the features of a simple pneumothorax secondary to CVP line insertion. The appropriate management is to insert a tube thoracostomy in the 5th intercostal space, just anterior to the mid- axillary line. Tension pneumothorax should be suspected in the presence of trachea deviation and signs of impaired venous return, but these do not feature in this scenario. Haemothorax and chylothorax can also complicate CVP access, but are unlikely in the absence of a dull percussion note.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is blue-lighted into the emergency department following an accident at work. A pan of hot cooking oil had spilled over half of his back and over both his legs and he has sustained extensive burns in this distribution. He weighs 70 kg. Calculate the  volume of crystalloid this patient will require in the first 8 hours (from the time of his burn) of his treatment using the ATLS formula and the Wallace Rule of Nines.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

3,150 mL
Burn victims lose a lot of fluid following their injury and their treatment is notoriously difficult. The current ATLS guidelines formula is as follows:
Weight (kg) × % Burn × 2 = Volume of crystalloid required over 24 hours
The percentage burn is best calculated using the Wallace Rule of Nines:
• Head = 9%
• Arm=9%
• Leg = 18%
• Trunk front = 18%
• Back = 18%
Therefore, this patient has a percentage burn of 45%. Using this per- centage in the formula gives a volume of 6300 ml. Half of this should be given in the first 8 hours, the rest over the subsequent 16 hours. Obviously this is a rough guide and local practice will differ. All patients with this extent of injury should be managed in a specialist centre, typically in an intensive care unit. The take home message is that large volumes of fluid are required.

choices.text: Interventional radiology consultation for   visceral angiogram and embolization

questions.text: A 53-year-old female with remote history of necrotizing pancreatitis presents with massive UGI bleeding requiring intravenous fluids and blood transfusions.  After stabilization in the emergency department and transfer to the ICU,  EGD reveals large gastric varices with a red wale sign,  without esophageal varices. Which of the following is the definitive management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

RATIONALE The patient has a history of necrotizing pancreatitis that has resulted in obstruction of the  splenic vein with resultant isolated bleeding gastric varices.  Splenectomy is the definitive treatment of choice.  Gastric varices may be treated with injection of cyanoacrylate glue, but rebleeding is common and this is not widely available in the United States.  Banding can be done for gastric varices close to the GEJ (GOV-1),  but generally is not effective for other gastric varices.  Visceral angiogram with embolization is not a treatment option for gastric varices. Distal pancreatectomy would not treat splenic vein thrombosis.

questions.text: A 57-year-old female presents with intermittent abdominal pain,  heart burn and nausea.   The patient also reports diarrhea,  up to three to four loose bowel movements per day.  An upper endoscopy reveals esophagitis,  antral erythema with erosions and multiple small ulcerations in the duodenum.  Small bowel biopsies show inflammation with mild villous atrophy.   Celiac sprue serology and gastric biopsies are unremarkable.   The above clinical symptoms are most consistent with which of the following neuroendocrine tumors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

RATIONALE Gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome),  produces massive hypersection of gastric acid resulting in severe peptic ulcer disease and chronic diarrhea.   The majority (approximately 80 percent) of these tumors can be localized in the “gastrinoma triangle” in the region of the duodenum.   Secretin testing of patients with elevated gastrin levels can assist in the differentiation between gastrinoma and atrophic gastritis.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old female with history of alcohol abuse presented at an outside hospital two months ago with acute pancreatitis. Her hospital course was complicated by necrotizing pancreatitis and questionable pancreatic duct leak. She now presents to see you for persistent abdominal pain, early satiety and nausea, vomiting. Labs reveal WBC 9,000 cells/mm3, AST 52 U/L, ALT 30 U/L, alk phos 90 U/L, TB 1.5 mg/dl You get a repeat CT with contrast as below.   
What is collection noted on the CT?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

RATIONALE The revised Atlanta classification delineates the pancreatic cyst collections into a) acute peripancreatic fluid collection seen in the first four weeks, non-encapsulated peripancreatic fluid collections b) Pseudocysts develop after four weeks and well encapsulated c) acute necrotic collection occurs less than four weeks from the acute pancreatitis  d) walled off necrosis is after four weeks,  encapsulated necrosis as in this patient.

questions.text: 24-year-old female undergoes CT for abdominal pain and nausea.  CT,  as below,  revealed a 3.5 cm pancreatic tail cystic lesion with peripheral calcification,  though further evaluation is recommended with MRI.  She denies any history of pancreatitis or family history of pancreatic cancer. She denies any weight loss. MRI as below revealed the 3.5 cms hyperintense lobulated lesion with peripheral calcifications and possibly debris or solid component within.  Labs reveal a normal CBC and comprehensive metabolic panel. Amylase and lipase are normal.  CA 19-9 is 6 U/mL  (normal 0-35 U/mL).  EUS is performed for further evaluation and it reveals a solid hypoechoic mass with some calcifications without any obvious cystic areas.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

RATIONALE She has a pancreatic pseudopapillary tumor.  This is commonly seen in young female in their 20s or 30s.  They can occur anywhere in the pancreas.  On CT, a well encapsulated mass is seen with peripheral calcifications in up to 30 percent of patients. MRI reveals a well-defined lesion with high and low signal density on T1 and T2 weighted images, as seen in this patient. On EUS the lesions can be What is the most likely diagnosis? solid,  cystic or mixed and fluid CEA is low.  EUS 
FNA can have a 75 to 80 percent accuracy in diagnosing pancreatic pseudopapillary tumor.  Surgical resection is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female with no significant past medical history presents to the emergency department after a fall.  CT abdomen reveals a pancreatic neck three cm grape cluster-like cystic mass with a central scar. She is asymptomatic and has no abdominal pain, jaundice, weight loss or family history of pancreatic cancer. MRI is performed, that reveals a microcystic mass as below without any solid component. CBD and PD are normal in caliber. EUS is performed and fluid CEA is less than 5 ng/mL.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

RATIONALE This patient most likely has a serous cystadenoma. They are common in females and usually seen in their late 50s or 60s. CT and MRI can have a classic microcystic appearance with a central fibrous scar that can be seen in 30 percent of serous cysts and is considered pathognomonic. These are very vascular cysts and EUS FNA sample can be bloody, thus yield of cytology is low. Cyst fluid CEA concentration is usually low. Despite their benign nature, they can grow in size and cause abdominal pain, jaundice or weight loss. Therefore, surgery can be considered for the symptomatic serous cysts.

questions.text: An initial primary survey of the chest is intended to quickly identify the follow- ing causes of cardiorespiratory compromise, except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pulmonary contusion
The ATLS guidelines teach a method of rapid assessment of the trauma- tized patient divided into a primary survey, which is aimed at the identi- fication of immediate threats to life, and a secondary survey, which aims to identify more minor injuries. Thoracic injuries which are an immediate threat to life include, tension pneumothorax, open pneumotho- rax, massive haemothorax, tracheobronchial injury and cardiac tamponade. Pulmonary contusion is not an immediate threat to life, and therefore is not of initial concern during the primary survey. However, it can complicate recovery as the injured lung can impair gas exchange and may be more susceptible to fluid overload.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man is admitted with a burn over his arm and anterior chest. The involved tissue includes the entire circumference of his upper arm. Following initial resuscitation, he is admitted for observation. You are called to assess him as he is beginning to complain of increasing pain and tightness in his forearm. On examination you note weak peripheral pulses, paraesthesia and pain on active movement of the fingers, hand and wrist. The next stage in management is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Escharotomy
Skin is inherently elastic and allows expansion and relaxation of underlying tissues. When skin is lost due to burns or other causes, fibrotic scarring occurs. When such injuries are circumferential, as in this case, healing can constrict underlying tissues, blood vessels and nerves. Limbs are vulnerable, as is the neck and even the chest, where extensive injury can restrict chest expansion and impair breathing.
The patient in this case is clearly exhibiting the signs of muscle com- partment compromise secondary to restricted blood supply. There is concomitant paraesthesia, which may be as a result of ischaemia or a direct result of nerve compression. Fluid resuscitation is not required and although an electrolyte imbalance should be ruled out it is unlikely to be causative. Angiography is not indicated. This patient requires urgent escharotomy (incision of scar tissue to release constricting pres- sure). Fasciotomy is rarely required in such cases, but may be indicated if vascular supply remains compromised for a prolonged period and true compartment syndrome develops.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male with no significant past medical history presents with dyspepsia and 15 kgs unintentional weight loss.  Labs reveal a normal CBC and comprehensive metabolic panel (including hepatic function panel).  EGD shows mild chronic inactive gastritis without any ulcers or concerning lesions. CT abdomen as below reveals a three cm pancreatic body mass that is encasing the celiac artery bifurcation. No metastasis is noted on CT. CA 19-9 is 500 U/mL (normal 0-35 U/mL) .  Endoscopic ultrasound is performed and FNA of the mass reveals pancreatic adenocarcinoma.  What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

RATIONALE He has locally advanced pancreatic cancer and thus is not currently a candidate for surgical resection.  According to the 2018 NCCN guidelines he should receive chemotherapy.  Induction chemotherapy can be given for four to six months,  followed by chemoradiation or SBRT if he does not develop systemic metastases.  If his performance status is good and he does have disease response to the chemotherapy,  then curative resection can be considered.  His Bilirubin is normal, thus he currently does not require ERCP. He currently does not have any significant cancer related pain and thus does not need evaluation by pain management.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female is admitted with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back,  associated with nausea and vomiting.  On admission her pulse is 90 beats per minute and BP 110/70 mm Hg.  On physical exam she has significant epigastric tenderness with mild guarding, but no rebound tenderness. Labs reveal lipase greater than 10,000 U/L,  AST 350 U/L, ALT 450 U/L, TB 6.5 mg/dL,  alkaline phosphatase 400 U/L,  WBC 20,000 cells/mm3. Ultrasound showed multiple gallstones in the gallbladder,  with dilated common bile duct measuring 1.5 cm in diameter.  She is started on aggressive IV fluids with lactated ringers and broad spectrum antibiotics. Three hours after admission she develops fever with temperature of 101.5 degrees F with HR of 100/min and BP 90/60 mm Hg. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

RATIONALE Patients with gallstone pancreatitis with clinical deterioration and clinical picture suggestive of ascending cholangitis should undergo urgent ERCP. Patients with mild biliary pancreatitis with no signs of biliary obstruction should undergo interval cholecystectomy as soon as possible once patient improves, ideally during the same hospitalization. ERCP in patients with biliary pancreatitis without evidence of biliary obstruction or cholangitis is not necessary. This patient has developed ascending cholangitis and thus will benefit from an urgent ERCP.

choices.text: Expectant management with repeat imaging in six weeks

questions.text: A 45-year-old female was recently admitted with gallstone pancreatitis and was hospitalized for one week. She is now five weeks out from her admission and is tolerating a low fat diet well. Today at her follow up appointment she denies any abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting. CT performed two days ago revealed a nine cm pancreatic fluid collection suggestive of a pseudocyst,  as seen below. Her WBC is 6,000 cells/mm3 and hepatic function panel is within normal limits.  Her amylase and lipase are within normal limits. She denies any early satiety or fever.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

RATIONALE Since this patient is asymptomatic and has no signs of infection,  it is reasonable to follow the patient clinically and with radiological surveillance of the cyst for improvement/resolution. Pseudocyst drainage is recommended for patients that are symptomatic,  have rapidly enlarging pseudocyst or infected pseudocysts.  If the pseudocyst is amenable to endoscopic drainage, then endoscopic drainage is preferred over surgical drainage.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents to your clinic for further nausea, vomiting and jaundice. On exam, her abdomen is soft, non-tender and not distended. Her sclera are anicteric. Laboratory studies are obtained and reveal a total bilirubin of 1.5 mg/dL, alkaline phosphatase of 24 IU/L, AST  18  IU/L, ALT 19 IU/L. Her MRCP image is shown here.  For definitive management, you recommend:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

RATIONALE This patient has a type I choledochal cyst. The risk of malignancy increases with age approaching 28 percent  in  one  series.  Most  cancers  are  seen  within the cyst or gallbladder. She should undergo cyst resection, cholecystectomy with hepaticoenterostomy if possible. While ERCP can help to better delineate her anatomy and may be requested prior to surgical intervention, it will not provide definitive management. EUS is unlikely to add any significant  information  and  is  not  necessary.  Given the malignant potential of this cyst, it should be resected, so further imaging or no additional therapy would not be appropriate in this scenario.

questions.text: A 40-year-old depressed and schizophrenic man jumps off a three-story window onto the street. Paramedics arrive on scene within 5 min, and he is rushed to the emergency department but loses vitals in the field and is dead on arrival (DOA). What is the most likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

High-energy rapid deceleration chest trauma is most commonly caused by a fall from greater than two stories or from a motor vehicle accident (e.g., steering wheel strik- ing the chest). This mechanism of injury is known to cause aortic injuries which may lead to aortic transection and ultimately death. Autopsy studies of aviation accidents demonstrate that more than 30% of deaths are due to aortic transection. Overall, immediate mortality is greater than 70%. The majority of patients die instantly of exsanguination. Of those who survive, 50% will die within 24 h. Patients will present with a widened mediastinum, deviation of the trachea to the right, and left-sided hemothorax on chest radiographs. They may also have fractures of bones (e.g., first rib, sternum, scapula) that are uncommonly broken as high energy is required to break them. The aortic tear is usually at the ligamentum arteriosum, located just dis- tal to the left subclavian take off, as the aortic arch is relatively fixed to that point. CT angiogram can confirm the diagnosis, and definitive management includes operative repair. Although a ruptured spleen can lead to significant blood loss, instant death is highly unlikely (D). The remaining choices can all cause instant death, but they occur in less frequency than thoracic aortic transection with this mechanism of injury (B) Abdominal aortic transection is extremely rare following blunt trauma as it is more mobile than the thoracic aorta (C).

questions.text: Following a motor vehicle crash (MVC), a 35-year-old male is found to have a significant right-sided renal hilar injury on imaging. He becomes hemodynamically unstable, despite intravenous fluid resuscitation and massive transfusion protocol. The decision is made to take him to the OR. What incision should you use?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Complete midline vertical incision. Trauma nephrectomies should always be approached with a laparotomy or complete midline incision. The other approaches would not be appropriate in this clinical setting.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman who underwent cholecystectomy three days previously presents to the ED for further evaluation of RUQ abdominal pain and fevers.  On physical exam her abdomen is tender in the RUQ with guarding and rebound.  Labs reveal a total bilirubin of 2 mg/dL, alkaline phosphatase of 150 IU/L,  AST 60 IU/L, ALT 82  IU/L, lipase 50 U/L  (50 ULN), WBC 16.4 10^9/L.  Cross sectional imaging is performed and reveals this finding seen here. The next best step in management is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

RATIONALE This patient has a symptomatic bile leak post cholecystectomy and percutaneous drainage should be performed.  Percutaneous drainage will allow for confirmation of the diagnosis,  if the fluid is analyzed for bile, as well as source control.  While ERCP has been shown to be highly effective for treatment  of  bile  leaks,  it  will  do  little  to  hasten  an already formed symptomatic fluid collection that may or may not be communicating with the duct. Surgical revision should be considered if percutaneous drainage and or ERCP fail to resolve the leak,  or if a transection injury occurs,  as this is unlikely to be amenable to endoscopic therapy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to your clinic for further evaluation of RUQ abdominal pain. The patient reports intermittent RUQ pain which occurs every two to three months.  It typically will last 30 minutes to one hour and resolve. In between episode she feels well. It is not improved with acid suppression or bowel movements.  She underwent cholecystectomy for cholecystitis 10 years prior.  LFTs have been obtained during these episodes.  Labs following her most recent episode reveal a total bilirubin of 1 mg/dL,  alkaline phosphatase of 50 IU/L, AST 103 IU/L,  ALT 110 IU/L, and lipase of 10 U (ULN 50 U).  A prior episode six months ago revealed a similar elevation in her AST and ALT.  MRCP was performed and revealed a CBD which measured five millimeters without evidence of a filling defect. EUS is performed and is unrevealing. You recommend:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

RATIONALE This patient fulfills criteria for functional biliary sphincter of Oddi disorder (type II SOD). She has biliary type pain and has had elevated liver enzymes with episodes of pain. Structural etiologies for biliary have been excluded. In this patient, ERCP with biliary manometry is a reasonable approach. If manometry is positive, a biliary sphincterotomy should be performed. ERCP in patients with functional biliary sphincter of Oddi disorder carries a very high risk of post ERCP pancreatitis. In those who fulfill criteria, have positive manometry and are properly selected, long term improvement with sphincterotomy has been shown in up to 70-90  percent of patients. Fiber supplements, dicyclomine and narcotic pain medications have not been shown to be effective for biliary sphincter of Oddi disorder and are unlikely to improve the patient’s underlying pain

choices.text: A repeat US in one year

questions.text: A 36-year-old man with recurrent RUQ pain associated with meals is seeing you in clinic.  Aminotransferase levels have been measured with these episodes and have been normal.  He underwent a RUQ US which did not reveal cholelithiasis;  however, an 11-mm non-mobile echogenic lesion was noted within the gallbladder wall.  You recommend:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

RATIONALE Polypoid gallbladder lesions are seen in up to five  percent of adults in Western populations. Polypoid lesions can be pseudopolyps including cholesterol polyps, inflammatory polyps,  adenomyoma which are benign or true polyps including adenocarcinomas as well as adenomas (which have malignant potential).  A prior series noted that only polyps six mm or larger in size were found to have malignancy however in a more recent series malignancy was noted in polyps as small as three mm.  In patients with polyps that are greater than or equal to 10 mm,  cholecystectomy is recommended.  If the polyp is smaller than 10 mm and the patient is felt to have symptoms attributable to the polyp,  cholecystectomy is suggested.  If polyps are smaller than 10 mm without symptoms, ultrasound surveillance is recommended.   In this patient, the polyp is larger than 10 mm and he should undergo a cholecystectomy.  Given the size,  surveillance with US is not recommended. MRCP or CT is likely to be of limited utility in this scenario.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with no significant past medical history presents to your office for further management of right upper quadrant pain over the last one year.  The patient reports intermittent episodes of severe 9/10 RUQ pain every two to three weeks. The pain typically lasts one to two hours and resolves spontaneously.  She has no improvement with defecation. On exam her abdomen is soft not tender or distended. Labs obtained during one of her pain episodes show an AST of 14 IU/L, ALT 24 IU/L, Bili 0.8 mg/dL,  ALP 92 IU/L, and lipase of 32 U. She has undergone RUQ ultrasound without stones or sludge.  There is no pericholecystic fluid or wall thickening. Endoscopic ultrasound was performed,  and a four millimeter CBD was visualized with no microlithiasis within the CBD or gallbladder. The ampulla was normal in appearance as well as the remainder of her upper GI tract.  CCK- stimulated cholescintigraphy is obtained and demonstrates a GBEF of 22 percent. This patient most likely has:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

RATIONALE This patient fulfills criteria for a functional gallbladder disorder.  She has biliary type pain along with an absence of a structural etiology for her pain.  The diagnosis is further supported by low EF seen on cholescintigraphy as well as normal LFTs and lipase. Functional gallbladder disorder is a common indication for cholecystectomy occurring in approximately 10-20 percent of adults who undergo cholecystectomy.  The role of biliary and/or pancreatic sphincter dysfunction in patients with an intact gallbladder is controversial, as the intact GB is felt to serve a pressure offset. Current criteria require a prior cholecystectomy to diagnosis a functional biliary or pancreatic disorder.  In addition, the patient does not have abnormalities in her LFTs,  lipase or ductal dilation.  The patient does not have sludge, pericholecystic fluid or gallbladder wall thickening,  eliminating acalculous cholecystitis.  The patient does not report postprandial fullness early satiety or epigastric burning or pain to suggest dyspepsia as a likely etiology.

choices.text: Periorbital ecchymoses,  CSF otorrhoea, retroauricular ecchymoses, cranial nerve III palsy
Periorbital ecchymoses,  CSF rhinorrhoea, anosmia, cranial nerve VI palsy
Rib fracture, CSF otorrhoea, CSF rhinorrhoea, anosmia
Periorbital ecchymoses, CSF otorrhoea, CSF rhinorrhoea, retroauricular ecchymoses

questions.text:
Which of the following sets of clinical signs are usually associated with a basal
skull fracture?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Basal (or basilar) skull fractures are linear fractures that can be caused by head injury due to a blow at the back of the head or sudden deceleration, as occurs in traffic accidents. Classically, clinical features of this injury are:
• Periorbital ecchymoses (raccoon or panda eyes)
• Retroauricular ecchymoses (Battle’s sign is ecchymosis of the mastoid process)
• Otorrhoea and rhinorrhoea (the leak of cerebrospinal fluid into the ears and nose respectively)
• Haemotympanum
• Anosmia
• Cranial nerve VII (facial nerve) palsy
• Depressed skull fracture (‘step off’) – this is associated with an increased incidence of intracranial injury, early seizures and a risk of intracranial injury

choices.text: A 50-year-old woman with a 1% TBSA partial-thickness burn on her left hand from a cooking accident
A 30-year-old construction worker with pain and blistering bilaterally on the knees after kneeling in wet cement all afternoon
A 25-year-old man with 7% TBSA partial-thickness burns on the chest
A 42-year-old woman with no cutaneous injury, found lying down at the scene of a house fire, and noted

questions.text: Which of the following patients do not meet the criteria for referral to a burn center?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Guidelines for patient referral to a burn center for care: (1) partial thickness burns on greater than 10% of TBSA; (2) burns that involve the face, hands, feet, genitalia, perineum, or major joints;(3) third-degree burns (any size) in any age group; (4) electrical burns, including lightning injury; (5) chemical burns; (6) inhalation injury; (7) burn injury in patients with preexisting medical disorders that could complicate management, prolong recovery, or affect mortality; (8) any patient with burns and concomitant trauma (such as fractures) in which the burn injury poses the greatest risk for morbidity or mortality (in such cases, if the trauma poses a greater immediate risk, the patient’s condition may be stabilized initially in a trauma center before transfer to a burn center); (9) burned children in hospitals without qualified personnel or equipment for the care of children; and (10) burn injuries in patients who will require special social, emotional, or rehabilitative intervention.

choices.text: Surgical consultation with consideration of  therapeutic upper endoscopy

questions.text: An 89-year-old woman presents with black stools as well as RUQ pain radiating to her shoulder as well as nausea and vomiting. She denies any prior episodes of abdominal pain. On exam, her abdomen is distended and tender to palpation. Labs are notable for a WBC of 18.2, Hgb 10 gm/dl, previously 12, ALT 147 IU/L, AST 376 IU/L, T bilirubin 2.8 mg/dl. CT imaging reveals a markedly dilated stomach without small bowel dilation. The gallbladder is heterogenous in appearance with several calcified stones. The GB wall is thickened and appears inseparable from the adjacent duodenum. Air is seen within the gallbladder lumen. The CBD is not dilated. She has no prior history of biliary instrumentation. The next best step in management of this condition is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

RATIONALE This patient has gastric outlet obstruction secondary to a gallstone that has formed a cholecystoduodenal fistula or Bouveret’s syndrome. Bouveret’s is a rare cause of obstruction of the GI tract by gallstones representing approximately two percent of all gallstone ileus cases. It should be suspected in patients with gastric outlet obstruction and unexplained pneumobilia. The therapeutic approach should start with an endoscopy; however, this is only successful approximately nine percent of the time. Surgery is often required for definitive management and it is reasonable to have them involved upfront given the low success rate endoscopically. It should be noted that surgical intervention carries an approximately 12 percent mortality rate, likely due to the advanced age and the medical comorbidities of these patients.  In this scenario, the stone has eroded into the duodenal bulb and neither EUS or ERCP will be of benefit. NG tube placement will allow for decompression of the stomach, but it will not resolve the obstruction. Percutaneous drain placement would not be of benefit in this scenario.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to your clinic for further evaluation of abdominal pain.  On exam, the patient’s abdomen is soft, not tender and not distended. You note icteric sclerae. Labs are obtained and demonstrate an AST of 92 IU/L, ALT 87 IU/L, Bili 3 mg/dL, ALP 180 IU/L, and lipase is 23 U/L. A RUQ ultrasound demonstrates ductal dilation but no cholelithiasis or sludge. MRCP is subsequently performed and is shown here.  ERCP is performed with the image shown .The most common clinical presentation of this condition is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

RATIONALE This patient has a choledochocele.  While many are asymptomatic,  the most common clinical presentation is pancreatitis,  which is seen in 38-70 percent of patients with a choledochocele. Jaundice is seen in 11-25 percent of patients and cholangitis is seen in 0-10  percent of patients. The most common presentation of choledochal cysts type I,  II,  IV,  V  is cholangitis, followed by obstructive jaundice,  then pancreatitis.  Diarrhea and GI bleeding are not typical presentations of choledochal cysts.  This is the only type of choledochal cyst for which ERCP can offer definitive management.  The risk of malignancy is very low, especially when compared to other choledochal cysts, and the need for surveillance following endoscopic management (snare resection or sphincterotomy) remains controversial.

choices.text: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney   disease is the most common renal   manifestation.
Cyst aspiration and sclerotherapy are   indicated.
This patient is at increased risk for   cholangiocarcinoma.
This patient’s liver disease is secondary   to parasitic infection.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the emergency room with abdominal pain, recurrent fevers, and worsening jaundice. He has a past medical history significant for recurrent episodes of cholangitis, ascites, and esophageal varices.  A CT scan (below) is performed in the emergency room.  MRCP performed several weeks earlier is shown below: Which of the following is true regarding this  patient’s diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

RATIONALE  This patient has Caroli’s syndrome which is a congenital disorder characterized by multifocal, segmental dilation of large intrahepatic bile ducts associated with congenital hepatic fibrosis.   The diagnosis of Caroli’s syndrome is established by imaging studies.   This patient’s cholangiogram illustrates characteristic features of Caroli’s syndrome including diffuse dilation of the biliary tree with extensive fusiform and saccular dilation of the intrahepatic bile ducts.  Other characteristic radiographic features (indicated by arrowheads on CT scan) include the “central dot sign” where intraluminal portal vein radicals appear as foci of contrast enhancement within the dilated bile ducts.  Biliary cysts in Caroli’s syndrome are irregularly shaped and communicate with the bile ducts.  In contrast, cysts in polycystic liver disease are more regularly shaped and do not communicate with bile ducts.  Renal manifestations occur in up to 60 percent of patients with Caroli’s syndrome and include medullary sponge kidney, cortical cysts, autosomal-recessive polycystic kidney disease, or very rarely, autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease.  Patients with Caroli’s syndrome are at increased risk for cholangiocarcinoma which is thought to be due to bile stasis and high concentrations of unconjugated secondary bile salts.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents to the office after Roux-en-Y surgery for weight loss.  She has a strong family history of gallstones, and asks about measures to prevent gallstone formation after her surgery.    Which of the following agents has potential efficacy to reduce gallstone formation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

RATIONALE Risk factors for gallstone formation include increased age, female gender, pregnancy, dyslipidemia, diabetes, obesity and rapid weight loss – especially after gastric bypass surgery.  Medications such as hormone replacement therapies/ oral contraceptive agents, fibrates, somatostatin analogues also increase gallstone risk.  Currently, there is evidence suggesting potential benefit of prophylactic cholecystectomy during Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, given the potential risk of gallstone formation with rapid weight loss following surgery.  However, there is also data from randomized controlled trials that the use of ursodeoxycholic acid following surgery may help reduce risk of gallstone formation for this group of patients.

choices.text: Endoscopic Band ligation and start nadolol

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman with hepatitis B cirrhosis was admitted after a witnessed episode of hematemesis. She is currently in the intensive care unit and is intubated and sedated. Vitals include T 98.0o F, BP of 104/62 mmHg, HR 88 beats per minute. Abdomen is soft without ascites. Labs include AST 60 U/L, ALT 40 U/L, total bilirubin of 2.1 mg/dL, albumin of 3.2 g/dL, Hemoglobin of eight g/dL, INR 1.2, and a platelet count of 75,000/µL. She is started on antibiotics and an octreotide infusion. You perform an upper endoscopy and there is fresh clot in stomach and large esophageal varices with red wale signs. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

RATIONALE   Non-selective beta-blockers plus variceal ligation are recommended for secondary prophylaxis of variceal hemorrhage. Patients who survive an episode of acute variceal hemorrhage have a very high risk of rebleeding and death. The median rebleeding rate in untreated individuals is around 60 percent within the first one to two years. TIPS evaluation could be considered if the patient continued to bleed despite band ligation or if she were Child’s C and this were her first presentation.

choices.text: Transport to the operating room for exploratory thoracotomy

questions.text: An 18-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a stab wound to the chest. He is combative and with severe shortness of breath. His blood pressure is 94/76 mmHg with a pulse of 120/min and respiratory rate of 28/min. Physical exam reveals a 2 cm stab wound on the left chest. Lung fields on the left have decreased breath sounds and are hyperresonant to percussion. His neck veins are distended. A needle is placed in the left second intercostal midclavicular line and aspirated until a gush of air is heard escaping the chest wall. A liter of normal saline is given, and blood pressure improves to 120/70 mmHg, and pulse decreases to 100/min. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

This patient has a left-sided tension pneumothorax as confirmed by hypotension, distended neck veins, decreased breath sounds, and hyperresonant left chest. Immediate treatment is with needle thoracostomy, allowing for immediate thoracic decompression. This is preferred in the setting of a tension pneumothorax as it is faster than a chest tube but provides only temporary relief. All these patients require a tube thoracostomy (chest tube) immediately following needle thoracostomy. Tension pneumothorax is considered a clinical diagnosis, and confirmation with imaging is not recommended as it delays definitive care in the unstable patient

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient has been in the burn intensive care unit(ICU) intubated and sedated for 2 weeks after an 80% TBSA burn. He suddenly develops hypotension, tachycardia, and melena. What type of surgical problem is this patient mostlikely to have?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Curling’s ulcer is upper gastrointestinal bleeding in aburn patient, related to gastritis. Incidence is now decreased to4% due to improved critical care, chemical ulcer prophylaxis,and early tube feeding. A Cushing’s ulcer is similar, but presentsin patients with severe neurologic injury and is likely related toincreased intracranial pressure.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with recently diagnosed hepatitis B is in your office for further evaluation for new diagnosis of liver cancer.  He has no other past medical history and is a former smoker.  He recently started tenofovir. His exam is notable for palpable hepatomegaly without evidence of jaundice,  spider angiomata, or palmar erythema.  His current blood work includes AST 120 U/L, ALT 150 U/L, sodium of 137 mEq/L, total bilirubin of 1.8 mg/dL, albumin of 3.7 g/dL, creatinine of 1.0 mg/dL,  INR of 1.0 and a platelet count of 150,000/µL.  You review his most recent MRI,  which reveals a three centimeter segment 3 lesion and a two centimeter segment 7 lesion.  Both lesions demonstrate arterial enhancement and venous washout.  There is no evidence of vascular invasion or extrahepatic disease. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

RATIONALE   Management of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) includes liver transplant evaluation regardless of decompensation. Liver transplantation is an effective option for patients with up to three tumors within Milan criteria: three lesions each measuring less than three centimeters, or a single lesion less than five centimeters without evidence of vascular invasion or extrahepatic disease. Surgical resection should be considered in patients with a single mass (usually less than f ive centimeters) in the setting of good liver function and absence of clinically significant portal hypertension. Ablation with or without transarterial chemoembolization (TACE) has been used as a bridge to liver transplantation for controlling tumor burden. TACE is recommended for nonsurgical candidates who have reasonable liver function and multinodular tumors that are beyond Milan criteria. Sorafenib is a multikinase inhibitor with antiproliferative properties that is reserved for those patients with advanced HCC who are not candidates for locoregional treatment and have good liver function.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male was accidentally struck on the side of his head by a cricket bat. On arrival at the Emergency Department he was unconscious, with bruising over the region of his right temporal region and an ipsilateral dilated pupil. CT scan demonstrated a fracture of the region marked in the picture below. Which of the following arteries is most likely to have been damaged?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The middle meningeal artery is a branch of the maxillary artery, which in itself is a terminal branch of the external carotid artery. It supplies only the bones of the skull and not any intracranial structures. The anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery lies beneath the pterion, which is formed at the site of fusion of the frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoidal bones. The surface marking for this is two finger breadths behind the zygomatic arch and a thumb’s breadth behind the frontal process of the zygomatic bone. It is important to know this landmark as it is the site where an emergency burr hole may be created to drain an extradural haematoma.

choices.text: Cultured epidermal autografts have dramatically increased survival in patients with nearly 100% TBSA burn injuries.
Allografting to burn wound sites is limited to temporary closure because of eventual rejection of the graft by the patient.
Porcine xenograft has the advantage of better early vascularization and engrafting after placement as a result of decreased antigenicity in comparison to most cadaveric human allografts.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the skin substitutes used in burn reconstruction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Human allograft has been widely used as a temporary biologic dressing. It is usually meshed to allow drainage of fluid and applied in a similar fashion to other skin grafts. Allograft will vascularize and engraft, provide wound closure for 2 to 4 weeks, and subsequently be rejected and need tobe replaced with new allograft or autograft if available. Sheets ofallograft may be placed over widely meshed autograft at the timeof surgery to protect grafts as the interstices epithelialize. Porcine  xenograft is cheaper and more easily stored before use, but it doesnot vascularize and engraft. It may be used similar to allograft for temporary biologic coverage of burn wounds, as well as for exfoliative diseases of the skin (e.g., TEN). Cultured epidermal autografts grown from patient keratinocytes are promising as a skin substitute but are not yet in widespread availability and are associated with high cost and complexity. Dermal substitutes such as the Integra Dermal Regeneration Template (Integra Lifesciences, Plainsboro,NJ) have seen more clinical use.

choices.text: The external jugular vein can be ligated if the internal jugulars are intact.
The internal jugular vein may be ligated unilaterally.
The external carotid artery can be safely ligated.
Unilateral ligation of the internal carotid may be safely performed.

questions.text: Regarding the surgical management of vascular injuries in the neck, all of the following are correct except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Comments The rich anastomotic networks of the blood vessels in the head and neck allow the preservation of blood flow even when some of the blood vessels are compromised.
When an external jugular vein is ligated, venous return is redirected towards the contralateral vessel, as well as to the ipsilateral internal jugular. Ligation of the external carotid artery is compensated through multiple collaterals to the contra- lateral external carotid, as well as with the internal carotid artery, through the angular artery.
The internal jugular vein may be ligated unilaterally without a negative impact on intracranial pressure. However, acute simultaneous bilateral ligation results in engorgement of the intracranial venous system, compromising cerebral blood flow. It has been shown in experimental models that preservation of the external jugular veins ameliorates the increase in intracra- nial pressures 
The internal carotid artery behaves as an end artery, although blood flow to the ipsilateral brain can be partially restored through the circle of Willis. Its ligation is associated with a stroke rate of 20 % and a mortality rate as high as 25 %, which makes this maneuver extremely risky.
Although it would seem that ligation of the common carotid artery would result in reconstitution of flow to the internal carotid through the contralateral anastomoses of the external carotid artery, this is unfortunately not the case. What occurs is that flow to the internal carotid on the ligated side is restituted by the circle of Willis. Blood is then diverted from the internal carotid to the external carotid, further compromising brain perfusion in a manner analogous to the subclavian steal syndrome

questions.text: A 53-year-old man with NASH cirrhosis is in the office for a follow up.    His albumin is 2.9 g/dl,  ALT is 89 U/mL.   A contrasted CT of the liver shows arterial enhancement of a three centimeter lesion with continuous heterogenous filling in later phases.  On ultrasound it appears hyperechoic.   The  most  likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

ATIONALE Hepatocellular carcinoma is the first consideration in the assessment of a liver lesion in a patient with cirrhosis, however other conditions should be on the differential diagnosis of a liver mass. On contrasted CT of the liver,  a hepatoma demonstrates arterial enhancement, washout on late images and an enhanced capsule. A hemangioma appears well demarcated with peripheral enhancement,  homogenous more often than heterogenous and delayed washout.  An FNH shows a homogenous arterial filling with a central scar and can be iso- or hypodense on delayed phases.  An adenoma is benign but at risk of degeneration when it reaches five centimeter in diameter and beyond. It demonstrates arterial enhancement and is hypodense on hepatobiliary phase relative to the liver tissue.

choices.text: He should be referred for liver transplantation
Given absence of cirrhosis, he should be offered reassurance and repeat imaging in one year to ensure stability
His liver lesion is likely related to occupational exposure to vinyl chloride
His risk of intraperitoneal bleeding is low

questions.text: A 70-year-old man is referred for evaluation of fatigue, weight loss, and elevated LFTs. An MRI of the liver shows a three cm suspected cavernous hemangioma in the liver, multiple small nodules in the spleen, and trace ascites, but no evidence of cirrhosis. He does not drink alcohol and tested negative for viral hepatitis. He is concerned, because his younger brother died from a bleeding liver tumor, and they worked at the same factory where they were exposed to “lots of chemicals”. Which of the following is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

RATIONALE This presentation is concerning for metastatic hepatic angiosarcoma, especially in light of the reported history of a coworker (in this case his brother) who died of a rare liver tumor.  Hepatic angiosarcomas are related to occupational exposure to vinyl chloride, an agent used in chemical manufacturing. It can be misdiagnosed on imaging as cavernous hepatic hemangiomas, but a hemangioma would not be expected to be associated with abnormalities in LFTs, ascites, or splenic nodules. The risk of intraperitoneal bleeding is estimated to be roughly 25 percent and can complicate attempts at needle biopsy. Suggested treatment for hepatic angiosarcoma involves local excision and transarterial embolization, particularly in the case of intraperitoneal bleeding. Some argue that hepatic angiosarcoma is a contraindication to liver transplantation given poor outcomes, and this patient would not be a candidate for liver transplantation given likely metastasis to spleen. Hereditary hepatic hemangioma syndrome is not a real clinical entity.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is NOT associated with increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

RATIONALE A number of conditions are associated with in creased risk of cholangiocarcinoma. The lifetime risk of biliary cancer in Lynch syndrome is estimated to be one to four percent in individuals with mutations in  MLH1  and  MSH2. Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) carries a six to 36 percent lifetime risk. Choledochal cysts, especially type I (solitary, extrahepatic) and type IV (extra- and intrahepatic), increase the risk of cholangiocarcinoma with a lifetime risk of 6-30 percent. Liver fluke infections with  Opisthorchis viverrini  (O. viverrini) and  Clonorchis sinensis  (C. sinensis) are risk factors for cholangiocarcinoma. These infections are most common in Southeast Asia. Cholelithiasis has not been identified as a risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old man presented to the Emergency Department with a 4-week history of rigors, weight loss, and right sided abdominal pain which radiated to his right shoulder. He had returned from a business trip to China 9 months ago. He reported two episodes of fresh rectal bleeding on return to the UK following his trip.

On examination, he had a temperature of 39°C, blood pressure of 100/60 mmHg, heart rate of 90 beats/minute, and hepatomegaly.

Investigations:

Hg -140 g/dL (130–180)

TLC- 22 x 109/L (4.0–11.0)

PT- 14 seconds

 CT abdomen.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Given the history of travel and clinical features this is a case of amoebic liver abscess. CT picture also shows large hypodense lesion with peripheral rim encancement. History of rectal bleed suggest amoebic colitis in this patient.

choices.text: CT scan of the head is the standard imaging modality that reveals cranial EDH without the need for IV contrast.
EDH is usually crescentic in shape on CT imaging, while a SDH is more lenticular with biconvex borders.
The fresh, undiluted blood on an EDH appears as a hypodense mass on head CT scan.
A positive swirl sign on a CT scan of the head indicates a long-standing EDH, which can be treated conservatively.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with altered level of consciousness following direct trauma to the head by a heavy object about 3 hours prior to arrival. He was brought in by his friend, who said that he had transient loss of consciousness for about one minute after which he woke up complaining of headache and blurry vision.He vomited once before becoming somnolent and again about 30 minutes later.
On general examination, his vital signs were ,BP= 140/85mmHg,RR= 18cycle/min,Pulse= 68 beat/min, and GCS = 10/15. Bruises were seen over the right temple. On neurological examination, the patient had a left hemiparesis with round, equal, and reactive pupils. T e patient was mildly agitated with good localization of painful stimuli. 
Regarding the  diagnosis of cranial EDH,whichof the following is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

CT scanning oF the head usually shows a classic appearance of EDH which is a homogeneous hyper- dense extra-axial lenticular mass with convex bor- ders. IV post-contrast CT is very rarely needed in cases ofisodense EDH. a SDH is characterized on head CT as a crescentic mass with biconcave shape
A “swirl sign” is a distinct radiographic sign of active bleeding which may occur in different types of intracranialhemorrhage.Itpresentsasanareaof irregular density in the hyperdense clot and is typically of low attenuation (radiolucency). Its occurrence is associated with worse clinical outcomes and bigger sizes ofintracerebral hematomas represents an area of active ongoing bleeding

choices.text: For a diagnosis fracture of >2 ribs at > 2 locations

questions.text: A patient involved in a road traffic accident is brought to the surgery emergency with shortness of breath. HRCT was done.  A 3-D reconstruction of the ct is shown. True about this condition are all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

This condition usually results from blunt trauma associated with multiple rib fractures, and is defined as three or more ribs fractured in two or more places. The blunt force typically also produces an underlying pulmonary contusion. To confirm the diagnosis the chest wall can be observed for paradoxical motion of a chest wall segment. On inspiration, the loose segment of the chest wall is displaced inwards and therefore less air moves into the lungs. On expiration, the segment moves outwards (paradoxical respiration). Currently, treatment consists of oxygen administration, adequate analgesia (including opiates) and physiotherapy. If a chest tube is in situ, topical intrapleural local analgesia introduced via the tube, can also be used. Ventilation is reserved for cases developing respiratory failure despite adequate analgesia and oxygen.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a part of the Revised Trauma Score?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Pulse rate

RTS includes

– Respiratory rate

– Systolic blood pressure

– Glasgow coma scale

questions.text: The incision shown in the picture is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The initial execution of a clamshell thoracotomy should be done in hypotensive patients with penetrating wounds to the right chest. This provides immediate, direct access to a right-sided pulmonary or vascular injury while still allowing access to the pericardium from the left side for open cardiac massage. Clamshell thoracotomy may also be considered in patients with presumed air embolism, providing access to the cardiac chambers for aspiration, coronary vessels for massage, and bilateral lungs for obliteration of the source.

choices.text: The caudate lobe receives portal structures from both the right and left main branches.
The caudate process of the caudate lobe extends to and may make contact with segment 7 thus surrounding the inferior vena cava.
The caudate lobe is hypotrophic in Budd–Chiari syndrome.
The caudate lobe drains directly into the vena cava.

questions.text: All of the following are correct except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Comments The caudate lobe of the liver is unique in that it receives branches from both the right and left portal triads and drains directly into the inferior vena cava. It lies anterior to the cava. The caudate process of the caudate lobe, connecting segments I to VII, may encircle the vena cava to varying degrees.
The venous drainage of caudate lobe of the liver is not affected by thrombosis of the hepatic veins in Budd–Chiari syn- drome (hepatic vein thrombosis). Given that this lobe drains directly into the vena cava, its venous outflow is preserved. In fact, this lobe is noticeably enlarged, as it comes to replace the function of the remaining liver tissue.
Resection of the caudate lobe is practiced with increasing frequency and safety. It is commonly incorporated in right hepa- tectomies.

choices.text: Right internal jugular approach central line
Two wide-bore cannulae inserted bilaterally to the antecubital fossae

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is admitted following a stab injury to the right groin. He is bleeding profusely from the wound. His blood pressure is 80/40 mmHg and his pulse is 140 beats/min. He is agitated and mildly confused. His skin is cool and mottled. In this scenario, which is the best mode of fluid delivery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Two wide-bore cannulae inserted bilaterally to the antecubital fossae Optimal fluid volume delivery is through large-bore access achieved with cannulae inserted into the antecubital fossae. Central lines (answers A and C) are generally long conduits with narrow lumens and are therefore less effective at delivering large volumes to hypotensive trauma patients. The same is true of long lines inserted through a femoral approach. It may be necessary to perform a long saphenous venous cut-down, but this approach should be reserved for patients where attempts to obtain standard peripheral venous access have failed.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman was a pedestrian hit by a car while crossing the road. She complains of chest and abdominal pains. On examination, her GCS score is 14/15 (E4, V4, M6). Her vital observations are as follows: BP 86/32 mmHg; pulse 145/min. She has bruising and tenderness over her lower left 9th and 10th ribs. She has rebound tenderness and guarding over the left upper quadrant of her abdomen. Her chest X-ray demonstrates left rib fractures affecting ribs 8–10.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

This patient is presenting with a ruptured spleen (left lower rib fractures with associated hypotension) secondary to trauma. Patients present with abdominal pain, left shoulder tip pain (Kehr’s sign), hypotension and tachycardia. Bruising may present over the left upper abdomen, left chest, or left lower back and is associated with underlying haemorrhage.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man is involved in a road traffic accident. He was a driver of a delivery truck, travelling at 50 miles/h and was hit from the side. On arrival at A&E he is unstable. His vital observations are as follows: BP 90/32 mmHg; pulse 160/min; respirator rate 45 breaths/min. On examination, his neck veins are engorged and distended. His trachea is central with quiet heart sounds.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The patient has a cardiac (pericardial) tamponade. The clinical syndrome is caused by accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space, which results in reduced ventricular filling and subsequent haemodynamic compromise. Cardiac tamponade presents with Beck’s triad: quiet and muffled heart sounds, hypotension and distended neck vein (jugular venous distention). An emergency pericardiocentesis is the life-saving treatment of choice.
